Column Comment.0: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Valid entries may be SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.1: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.Valid types of seismic sets are SEIS_LINE, SEIS_3D, SEIS_SEGMENT andSEIS_SURVEY.
Column Comment.2: RECORD_ID: Unique identifier for the seismic record that was created duringacquisition.
Column Comment.3: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.4: ACQUISITION DESIGN ID: Unique identifier for the acquisition design.
Column Comment.5: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.6: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.7: FIELD FILE NUMBER: The file number assigned to the shot in the field. This may notcorrespond to the file number on a tape that is copied from the original.
Column Comment.8: INFORMATION ITEM ID: Unique identifier for the information item.
Column Comment.9: INFORMATION ITEM SUBTYPE: the type of information item. May be one of Thevalid types of Information item as defined by check constraints.
Column Comment.10: LOGICAL RECORD NUMBER: The logical number of the record relative to otherrecords in the seismic set. Can be used to create a single concatenated set ofrecords for recording that covers more than one tape.
Column Comment.11: SEISMIC PATCH: This table is used to capture generalized recording patch designs.Details about the patch design are contained in the table SEIS_PATCH_DESC or asa digital file that is stored in the RM module. .
Column Comment.12: PATCH USED INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether a seismic patch was usedduring acquisition.
Column Comment.13: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.14: RECORDED CHANNELS COUNT: the number of channels included on this record
Column Comment.15: RECORDING REMARKS: remarks made by the observer during recording for thisrecord. Usually found on the observers logs.
Column Comment.16: RECORD NUMBER: the number of the record on the tape.
Column Comment.17: RECORD QUALITY: The quality of the record created during recording, includinggood, fair, poor.
Column Comment.18: RECORD TYPE: the type of seismic record, such as good record, bad data, testrecord etc.
Column Comment.19: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.20: SEISMIC SHOT POINT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for the seismic point that wasused as shot point to generate this record.
Column Comment.21: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.22: TAPE NUMBER: the number assigned to the tape on which the record was made.This is provided explicitly because the tape may not be catalogued in the RM systemwhen this information is collected. An additional relationship with RM INFO ITEMCONTENT isprovided for when the tape is added to the RM Module.
Column Comment.23: TIMING DELAY: Timing delay between shot and recording start (may be millisecondsor seconds in deep water)
Column Comment.25: UPHOLE TIME: the uphole time recorded on this record.
Column Comment.27: SEISMIC VESSEL CONFIGURATION OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifierfor this configuration of the seismic vessel.
Column Comment.28: VESSEL IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the marine vessel.
Column Comment.29: VESSEL SF SUBTYPE: supports the super sub type implementation. Value may onlybe SEIS VESSEL.
Column Comment.30: X OFFSET: The offset of this record from the nominal patch description.
Column Comment.31: Y OFFSET: The offset of this record from the nominal patch description.
Column Comment.32: Z OFFSET: The offset of this record from the nominal patch description.
Column Comment.33: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.34: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.35: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.36: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.37: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.38: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.39: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
